text:
Hi all, I'm Miguel.
I'm a first-year undergrad CS student in California (moved here from France 7 years ago). I usually do high-level stuff like web & game development, but have been getting interested in PL theory and other more theoretical aspects of computing. Wanting to learn more, I researched online and found this community. I'm excited to learn from (and maybe contribute to) the conversations on here.

elements.text:
Hi all, I'm Miguel.
I'm a first-year undergrad CS student in California (moved here from France 7 years ago). I usually do high-level stuff like web & game development, but have been getting interested in PL theory and other more theoretical aspects of computing. Wanting to learn more, I researched online and found this community. I'm excited to learn from (and maybe contribute to) the conversations on here.

text:
Coming back to this much much later, the thing that this all brings to mind for me is how nasty it used to be to make JavaScript look like class-based OO, and how the industry was starting to figure out than function closures (e.g. over passed arguments) are much better and really all you need ... until class _syntax_ was added to ES6 (with all the same problems) and everyone quickly forgot this lesson.

But anyway, now I see classes as a weaker clunkier model of closures.
